cytoscape
Class GraphObjAttributes

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--cytoscape.GraphObjAttributes
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable
public class GraphObjAttributes
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable

Store multiple attributes of multiple "graph objects" (usually graph nodes or edges) for easy and flexible retrieval. There is typically two instances of this class associated with every cytoscape graph: one set of attributes for all of the nodes, and another set of attributes for all the edges.

It may be useful to understand the implementation of this data structure, at least at a high level, in order to use it effectively. At the top level there is a hashtable, with one entry for each attribute; the attribute's name (a String) is the key to this top level hashtable. The value associated with each of these keys is another hashtable, in which are stored possibly many entries whose keys are node or edge names, and whose values are Vectors of java objects.

For example: 

   GraphObjAttributes nodeAttributes = new GraphObjAttributes ();

   nodeAttributes.add ("mRNA ratio",        "GAL4",  1.8);
   nodeAttributes.add ("mRNA ratio",        "GAL80", 0.01);

   nodeAttributes.add ("mRNA significance", "GAL4",  0.4);
   nodeAttributes.add ("mRNA significance", "GAL80", 0.8);

   nodeAttributes.add ("gene product",      "GAL4",  "zinc finger transcription factor");
   nodeAttributes.add ("gene product",      "GAL80", "transcriptional regulator");

   nodeAttributes.add ("SGD summary",       "GAL4", 
                       "http://genome-www4.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/SGD/locus.pl?locus=gal4");
   nodeAttributes.add ("SGD summary",       "GAL4", 
                       "http://genome-www4.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/SGD/locus.pl?locus=gal80");

These nine lines of code create 4 entries (and therefor 4 keys) in the top level hash: mRNA ratio, mRNA significance, gene product, and SGD summary. The values of each of these keys in the top level hash are each themselves hashtables, which have, in turn, just two entries (GAL4 and GAL80); the values of each of these second-level hashes are lists (java Vectors) of java objects, as follows:

  1. mRNA ratio:   java.lang.Double
  2. mRNA significance:   java.lang.Double
  3. gene product:   java.lang.String
  4. SGD summary:   java.net.URL
These classes (Double, String, URL) are deduced from the data, but you may also assign attribute classes explicitly: 
   nodeAttributes.setClass ("SGD summary", Class.forName ("java.net.URL"));
Each attribute also has a category, which by default is 'unknown', but which may be given any String value. There is as yet no controlled vocabulary for category names, but here are some suggestions which may be useful:
  • annotation:   useful if you want to do layout based on this attribute. Annotation is an exception to the general rule about category names: it is a privileged category, recognized elsewhere in cytoscape; for example, the Annotation Layout option uses it to recognize which of the current node attributes on nodes
  • data
  • categorizer
  • static web page

You may use cytoscape.props to specify attribute categories which are ignored by the NodeBrowser.

Here are some of the more common operations use in retrieving data from an instance of GraphObjAttributes, presented in no particular order: 

   if (nodeAttributes.hasAttribute ("mRNA ratio")) ...
   int genesWithSGDLinks = nodeAttributes.getObjectCount ("SGD summary");
   String [] allAttributeNames = nodeAttributes.getAttributeNames ();
   int attributeCount = nodeAttributes.numberOfAttributes ();
   Vector gal4mRNAList = attributes.getList ("mRNA ratio", "GAL4")
     // though all attribute values are really lists, those lists
     // often have just one member; if you know in advance that 
     // just a single mRNA ratio was stored for GAL4, and that it is
     // a Double, you can use this convenience method:
   Double gal4mRNA = attributes.getDoubleValue ("mRNA ratio", "GAL4");
     //
   Object [] values = attributes.getArrayValues ("gene product", "GAL4");
   String [] strings = attributes.getStringArrayValues ("gene product", "GAL4");
   String gal4Product = attributes.getStringValue ("geneProduct", "GAL4");

An Introduction to Attribute Files

It is very common to associate attributes with nodes and edges of a graph by reading them in on the cytoscape command line: 
   java cytoscape.cytoscape -i yeastGalactose.sif -n ratios.attr -n signif.attr -n products.attr -n sgdLinks.attr
Attribute files have the following form:
  1. a header line, containing at least an attribute name, and optionally class and category specifications
  2. one or more data lines, of the form <object name> = <object value>; white space may be used for either the name or the value
  3. <object value> may be a scalar (which, however, can include whitespace for strings) or a list, surrounded by parentheses, with each scalar delimited by "::"
  4. other tokens for list and token delmiters can be specified in your cytoscape.props

Attribute File Example 1

Create a String attribute named "animal species" of unknown category, for four nodes 

 animal species
 a = dog
 b = cat
 c = yak
 d = three-headed wolf

Attribute File Example 2

Create a URL attribute named "locusLink" of category annotation, for three nodes 

 locusLink (category=annotation) (class=java.net.URL)
 NM_000196 = http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/LocusLink/LocRpt.cgi?l=3291
 NM_000353 = http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/LocusLink/LocRpt.cgi?l=6898
 NM_001128 = http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/LocusLink/LocRpt.cgi?l=164

Attribute File Example 3

Create a String attribute named "GO molecular function, level 4" of category annotation, for four genes; some of the attribute values are multiple 

 GO molecular function, level 4 (category=annotation)
 AP1G1 = (intracellular::clathrin adaptor::intracellular transporter)
 HSD17B2 = (membrane::intracellular)
 E2F4 = (DNA binding)
 CDH3 = cell adhesion molecule

  1. create an example file and good documentation for an edge attributes file. how do we specify edge names these days? YPR065W (pp) YPR065W = 2232

clone in class java.lang.Object

addNameMapping

public void addNameMapping(java.lang.String canonicalName,
                           java.lang.Object graphObject)
establish mapping between a java object (a graph node or edge) and its canonical (standard) name.
  • clients of this class (CytoscapeWindow, or cytoscape plugins) usually deal with graph nodes and edges, and only secondarily with names;
  • attributes are stored and retrieved by canonical name
  • the client must be able to translate from the node or edge object to the name, in order to get at the attributes
  • this method allows a new mapping between object and canonical name.

    See Also:
    getCanonicalName(java.lang.Object)

public void clearNameMap()
remove all entries from the nameMap

getCanonicalName

public java.lang.String getCanonicalName(java.lang.Object graphObject)
return the canonical name associated with this graphObject (a node or edge, previously stored with a call to addNameMapping). if no mapping exists, null is returned.

add

public void add(cytoscape.GraphObjAttributes attributes)
copy all attributes in the supplied GraphObjAttributes object into this GraphObjAttributes

add

public boolean add(java.lang.String attributeName,
                   java.lang.String graphObjectName,
                   java.lang.Object obj)
add an attribute of the specified name to the graph object with the specified name. the attribute may be any java type, or an array of any java type; it can be neither a primitive value nor an array of primitves. if this attribute has not previously been assigned a class, either explicitly or implicitly, then the class is deduced from the object (or the first element in the array of objects). once a class has been assigned for this attribute, every subsequent addition must be an object of that same class.

Parameters:
attributeName - eg, "expression", "GO molecular function level 4", "tissue count"
graphObjectName - the canonical name of a node or edge
obj - the value of this attribute, either a java object or an array of java objects
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the class of obj (or of obj [0], if obj is an array) does not match the already assigned or deduced java class for this attribute

add

public boolean add(java.lang.String attributeName,
                   java.lang.String graphObjectName,
                   double value)
a convenience method; value will be promoted to Double

public java.util.HashMap getAttribute(java.lang.String attributeName)
return a hash whose keys are graphObjectName Strings, and whose values are a Vector of java objects the class of these objects, and the category of the attribute (annotation, data, URL) may be learned by calling getClass and getCategory

Returns:
a HashMap whose keys are graph object names (typically canonical names for nodes and edges) and whose values are Vectors of java objects.

getValue

public java.lang.Object getValue(java.lang.String attributeName,
                                 java.lang.String graphObjectName)
for backwards compatibility: the value of an attribute used to be strictly a single scalar; now -- even though attributes are all lists of scalars -- we support the old idiom by retrieving the first scalar from the list.

public java.lang.Double getDoubleValue(java.lang.String attributeName,

a convenience method backwardly compatible with the early versions of this class. assuming you are certain that the graphObject has a Double value for the named attribute, convert and return the first (and possibly only) element in the attribute Vector into a Double.

processFileHeader

public java.lang.String processFileHeader(java.lang.String text)
deduce attribute name, category, and java class from the first line of the attributes file. the form of the first line is 
  attribute name  (category=xxxx) (class=yyyy)
category and class are optional; if absent, class will be inferred (see deduceClass), and category set to DEFAULT_CATEGORY

readAttributesFromFile

public void readAttributesFromFile(java.io.File file)
                            throws java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                                   java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                   java.lang.NumberFormatException
read attributes from a file. there is one basic format for attribute files, but a few aspects of the format are flexible. the simplest form looks like this: 
  expresssion ratio
  geneA = 0.1
  geneB = 8.9
  ...
  geneZ = 23.2
In this form, the reader

java.io.FileNotFoundException
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
java.lang.NumberFormatException

getAttributes

for the graphObject named by canonicalName, extract and return all attributes

countIdentical

public int countIdentical(java.lang.String graphObjectName)
multiple GraphObj's (edges in particular) may have the same name; this method counts names which begin with the same string. for instance there may be two edges between the same pair of nodes: 
    VNG0382G (geneFusion) VNG1230G
    VNG0382G (geneFusion) VNG1232G
the first pair encountered may be give the name 
    VNG0382G (geneFusion) VNG1230G
we may wish to give the second pair the name 
    VNG0382G (geneFusion) VNG1230G_1
this method provides a count of matches based on String.startsWith ("VNG0382G (geneFusion) VNG1230G") which solves the problem of all subsequent duplicates simply append a number to the base name.

whoever calls this method must construct the new object's name -first- and then is expected to append "_N" where N is the value returned here (and of course, if the result is 0, there is no need to append '_0'
